title: Exodus Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Exodus chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Exodus Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Exodus Chapter 10.

questions.question: Who did the LORD say had a hardened heart in Exodus 10:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh and his servants
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:1 states that God hardened the heart of Pharaoh and his servants.

questions.question: According to Exodus 10:3, what did Moses and Aaron ask Pharaoh to do?
options: Let the people go to serve the LORD
Build a temple for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Let the people go to serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:3 shows Moses and Aaron asking Pharaoh to let the people go to serve the LORD.

questions.question: What plague did the LORD threaten to bring upon Egypt if Pharaoh refused to let the people go, according to Exodus 10:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Locusts
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:4 mentions the LORD threatening to bring locusts on Egypt.

questions.question: In Exodus 10:5, what did the locusts cover so that one could not see the earth?
questions.correctAnswer: The face of the earth
questions.explanation: The locusts covered the face of the earth so it could not be seen, as described in Exodus 10:5.

questions.question: How did Pharaoh's servants feel about Moses, according to Exodus 10:7?
options: They saw him as a snare
questions.correctAnswer: They saw him as a snare
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:7 states that Pharaoh's servants called Moses a snare to them.

questions.question: What did Moses say about who would go to serve the LORD in Exodus 10:9?
options: Young, old, sons, daughters, flocks, and herds
questions.correctAnswer: Young, old, sons, daughters, flocks, and herds
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:9 states that all—young, old, sons, daughters, flocks, and herds—would go.

questions.question: What kind of wind did the LORD bring upon Egypt to bring the locusts, according to Exodus 10:13?
questions.correctAnswer: An east wind
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:13 says the LORD brought an east wind to bring the locusts.

questions.question: How long did the darkness last over Egypt as described in Exodus 10:22?
questions.correctAnswer: Three days
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:22 tells us the darkness lasted three days.

questions.question: What did Pharaoh ask Moses and Aaron to do in Exodus 10:24?
options: Go serve the LORD but keep the flocks and herds
questions.correctAnswer: Go serve the LORD but keep the flocks and herds
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:24 records Pharaoh telling them to go serve the LORD but to keep the flocks and herds.

questions.question: What was Pharaoh's final response to Moses in Exodus 10:28?
options: Get thee from me, see my face no more
Let all the people go freely
questions.correctAnswer: Get thee from me, see my face no more
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:28 shows Pharaoh telling Moses to leave and not see his face again.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 10:20, the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart so he would not let the children of Israel go.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:20 clearly states that the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart.

questions.question: True or False: The locusts were destroyed by a strong west wind as told in Exodus 10:19.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:19 describes the LORD sending a mighty west wind that took away the locusts.

questions.question: True or False: In Exodus 10:23, the children of Israel also experienced the thick darkness for three days.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:23 says the children of Israel had light in their dwellings during the darkness.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Exodus 10:25: 'Thou must give us also sacrifices and ________, that we may sacrifice unto the LORD our God.'
questions.correctAnswer: burnt offerings
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:25 states they must be given sacrifices and burnt offerings.

questions.question: What did Moses say would happen if Pharaoh saw his face again, according to Exodus 10:29?
questions.correctAnswer: He would die that day
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:29 quotes Moses saying Pharaoh would die if he saw his face again.

medium.title: Exodus Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Exodus Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Exodus 10 teach us about trusting God's timing when facing trials?
options: God hardens hearts to show His signs before delivering
God immediately removes all suffering upon request
God expects us to control the outcome through our efforts
God punishes without reason or purpose
questions.correctAnswer: God hardens hearts to show His signs before delivering
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:1 shows God saying He has hardened Pharaoh's heart to display His signs, teaching us to trust God's timing and purpose in trials. This is supported by verses 20 and 27 where God again hardens Pharaoh’s heart for His divine purposes.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged because their prayers seem unanswered. Based on Exodus 10, what biblical truth about perseverance would you share?
options: God’s plan unfolds even when immediate results are not seen
Prayer is ineffective if results are not instant
God hardens all hearts to test believers' patience
We should stop praying if God delays
questions.correctAnswer: God’s plan unfolds even when immediate results are not seen
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:20 and 10:27 show that despite Moses' prayers and pleas, God hardened Pharaoh's heart, indicating God's plan unfolds over time and believers must persevere in faith and prayer.

questions.question: What does Exodus 10 teach about humility in approaching God through the example of Moses and Aaron’s requests to Pharaoh?
options: They respectfully ask Pharaoh to let the people go
They demand Pharaoh obey immediately with threats
They use deception to achieve their goal
questions.correctAnswer: They respectfully ask Pharaoh to let the people go
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:3 shows Moses and Aaron humbly and respectfully asking Pharaoh to let the people go, teaching us to approach opposition with humility and respect.

questions.question: How does Exodus 10 demonstrate the importance of family in spiritual obedience?
options: Moses says all, including sons and daughters, must go to serve the LORD
Only men are required to participate in worship
Children are to remain behind during sacrifices
Family members should be left to decide individually without guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Moses says all, including sons and daughters, must go to serve the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:9 highlights Moses' statement that young and old, sons and daughters, with their flocks and herds, must go, illustrating that spiritual obedience involves the whole family.

questions.question: Based on Exodus 10, how should believers respond when facing opposition at work or in daily responsibilities?
options: Continue faithfully serving God despite opposition
Give up and avoid conflicts at all cost
Use deceptive means to overcome opposition
Ignore God's commands to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfully serving God despite opposition
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:11 and 10:27 show that despite Pharaoh's refusal, Moses and the Israelites continued to obey God's command, teaching perseverance and faithfulness in daily duties.

questions.question: How does the removal of locusts by a strong west wind teach about God's power in delivering His people?
options: God controls nature to protect and deliver His people
People must fight natural disasters themselves
God is powerless against natural forces
questions.correctAnswer: God controls nature to protect and deliver His people
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:19 shows the LORD sending a mighty west wind to remove the locusts, demonstrating God's sovereign power over nature to deliver His people.

questions.question: What lesson about forgiveness and reconciliation is found in Pharaoh’s plea to Moses after the locust plague?
options: Pharaoh asks for forgiveness and Moses intercedes
Pharaoh refuses to admit any sin
Pharaoh blames others instead of God
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh asks for forgiveness and Moses intercedes
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:16-18 records Pharaoh admitting sin and asking Moses to intercede with God for forgiveness, highlighting the importance of confession and seeking reconciliation.

questions.question: How does Exodus 10 illustrate the importance of obedience in worship through Moses’ response to Pharaoh’s conditions?
options: Moses insists all sacrifices and animals must go with them
Moses accepts leaving animals behind to please Pharaoh
Moses agrees to worship without sacrifices
Moses compromises worship requirements for peace
questions.correctAnswer: Moses insists all sacrifices and animals must go with them
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:25-26 shows Moses refusing Pharaoh's partial permission, insisting their sacrifices and cattle go with them, teaching obedience in worship without compromise.

questions.question: What does the three days of thick darkness teach about God’s discipline and protection of His people?
options: Darkness was over Egypt but Israel had light in their dwellings
Darkness affected both Egyptians and Israelites equally
Israel also suffered the darkness without protection
Darkness was a natural occurrence without spiritual meaning
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness was over Egypt but Israel had light in their dwellings
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:22-23 describes a thick darkness over Egypt, but the Israelites had light in their homes, showing God’s discipline on the wicked and protection over His people.

questions.question: True or False: Pharaoh’s servants encouraged him to let the Israelites go because they recognized the destruction caused by the plagues.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:7 shows Pharaoh's servants urging him to let the Israelites go because they saw that Egypt was being destroyed by the plagues, demonstrating wisdom in recognizing God's judgment.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 10, Pharaoh immediately obeyed God’s command after the locust plague was removed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:27 and 10:20 state that the LORD hardened Pharaoh’s heart even after the locusts were removed, and he did not immediately let the Israelites go.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Moses told Pharaoh, "We will go with our young and with our old, with our sons and with our daughters, with our ____ and with our herds will we go."
questions.correctAnswer: flocks
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:9 records Moses saying they will go with their young, old, sons, daughters, flocks, and herds, emphasizing complete obedience and dependence on God.

questions.question: How can Exodus 10 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in difficult negotiations at work or church?
options: Moses clearly states their needs and refuses partial compromises
Moses uses trickery to gain an advantage
Moses agrees to Pharaoh's partial terms to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Moses clearly states their needs and refuses partial compromises
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:25-26 shows Moses honestly and firmly communicating God's requirements without yielding to Pharaoh’s partial offers, teaching integrity and honesty.

questions.question: What biblical virtue is demonstrated by Moses and Aaron continually returning to Pharaoh despite repeated refusals?
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance in obedience to God
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:3 and 10:8 show Moses and Aaron repeatedly coming to Pharaoh to deliver God's message, illustrating perseverance and commitment to God's calling.

questions.question: How does Exodus 10 teach about gratitude and contentment through the Israelites’ response to God’s commands?
options: They obey with all possessions and family, showing trust and gratitude
They complain about leaving possessions behind
They attempt to negotiate less demanding conditions
questions.correctAnswer: They obey with all possessions and family, showing trust and gratitude
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:9 and 10:26 reveal the Israelites' obedience with their families and possessions, indicating gratitude and contentment in trusting God's provision.

hard.title: Exodus Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Exodus Chapter 10.

questions.question: What is the significance of God hardening Pharaoh's heart as mentioned in Exodus 10:1?
options: To demonstrate God's power through signs
To show mercy to the Egyptians
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate God's power through signs
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:1 explains that God hardened Pharaoh's heart so that He might show His signs before him, emphasizing divine sovereignty and purpose.

questions.question: According to Exodus 10:2, for what purpose were the signs done in Egypt intended?
options: To be told to future generations
questions.correctAnswer: To be told to future generations
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:2 states that the signs were done so that Moses might tell his descendants what God had done, illustrating the importance of memory and covenant history.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Exodus 10:4, Moses warns Pharaoh that if he refuses to let the people go, God will bring ______ into his land.
questions.correctAnswer: locusts
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:4 specifically mentions that God will bring locusts upon Egypt if Pharaoh refuses to release the Israelites.

questions.question: What is the literary device used in Exodus 10:5-6 describing the locusts covering the earth and eating every plant?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole to emphasize devastation
questions.explanation: The vivid description of locusts covering the land and eating everything (Exodus 10:5-6) uses hyperbole to highlight the severity of the plague.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context is indicated by Pharaoh's servants urging him to let the Israelites go in Exodus 10:7?
options: They recognize the destruction caused by the plagues
They fear the Israelites' military power
They want to join the Israelites' religion
They seek personal gain from the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: They recognize the destruction caused by the plagues
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:7 shows Pharaoh's servants acknowledging Egypt's devastation, reflecting awareness of the plagues' impact within the ancient Near Eastern context.

questions.question: In Exodus 10:9, Moses insists that they will go with their young, old, sons, daughters, flocks, and herds. What does this insistence typologically foreshadow in Israel's history?
options: The comprehensive nature of Israel's Exodus
The division of Israel into tribes
questions.correctAnswer: The comprehensive nature of Israel's Exodus
questions.explanation: Moses' inclusion of all people and possessions (Exodus 10:9) foreshadows the total deliverance of Israel, a key typological theme in salvation history.

questions.question: How does the east wind mentioned in Exodus 10:13 relate to ancient Egyptian beliefs or environmental realities?
options: It was known to bring dry and destructive conditions
It was considered a symbol of fertility
It was the wind associated with the Nile's flooding
It was worshiped as a protective deity
questions.correctAnswer: It was known to bring dry and destructive conditions
questions.explanation: The east wind (Exodus 10:13) historically brought dry conditions that could foster locust swarms, connecting natural phenomena to divine judgment in the narrative.

questions.question: True or False: According to Exodus 10:15, the locusts spared some green plants and trees after the hail had fallen.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:15 states that the locusts ate every green thing left after the hail, leaving nothing behind, indicating total devastation.

questions.question: What theological theme is highlighted by Pharaoh's confession of sin and plea for forgiveness in Exodus 10:16-17?
options: Human repentance contrasted with divine sovereignty
The establishment of a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Human repentance contrasted with divine sovereignty
questions.explanation: Pharaoh's confession (Exodus 10:16-17) highlights human acknowledgment of sin but contrasts with God's ultimate control of events, as He again hardens Pharaoh's heart.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Exodus 10:19, the LORD sent a mighty strong ______ to remove the locusts and throw them into the Red Sea.
questions.correctAnswer: west wind
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:19 describes the LORD sending a strong west wind to remove the locusts, demonstrating divine intervention.

questions.question: What is the significance of the darkness described in Exodus 10:21-23, especially in the context of ancient Egyptian religion?
options: It symbolizes the defeat of Egyptian sun gods
It signals a new solar calendar
It is a metaphor for Israel's exile
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the defeat of Egyptian sun gods
questions.explanation: The palpable darkness (Exodus 10:21-23) challenges Egypt’s sun deity Ra, symbolizing divine judgment over Egyptian gods and power structures.

questions.question: How does Pharaoh's permission in Exodus 10:24 to let the Israelites go but keep their flocks and herds reflect ancient Near Eastern sacrificial practices?
options: He misunderstands the necessity of livestock for offerings
He intends to donate animals to their God
He wants to weaken Israel economically
questions.correctAnswer: He misunderstands the necessity of livestock for offerings
questions.explanation: Pharaoh's condition (Exodus 10:24) reveals a limited understanding of Israel's sacrificial system, which required animals, showing his resistance.

questions.question: What literary structure can be observed in the dialogue between Moses and Pharaoh throughout Exodus 10?
options: A chiastic pattern emphasizing escalating judgments
A parallel structure illustrating mutual respect
A narrative framed by a covenant blessing
A prophetic oracle with symbolic visions
questions.correctAnswer: A chiastic pattern emphasizing escalating judgments
questions.explanation: The chapter’s dialogue follows a chiastic structure with repeated appeals and increasing plagues, reinforcing the theme of hardened hearts and judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Exodus 10:20 indicates that after the locust plague, Pharaoh immediately let the Israelites go free.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:20 states that the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart again, so he did not let the Israelites go despite the plague.

questions.question: What is the significance of Moses’ final statement to Pharaoh in Exodus 10:29, 'I will see thy face again no more'?
options: It foreshadows their final confrontation in the next plague
It signals Moses' retirement from leadership
It means Moses will return to Egypt after exile
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows their final confrontation in the next plague
questions.explanation: Moses' statement (Exodus 10:29) anticipates the climactic final plagues and the eventual Exodus, marking a turning point in the narrative.

theological.title: Exodus Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Exodus Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason does God give Moses for hardening Pharaoh's heart in Exodus 10?
options: To demonstrate His power through signs
To punish Pharaoh for his pride
To allow the Israelites to escape unnoticed
To show mercy to Pharaoh's servants
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate His power through signs
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:1 states that God hardened Pharaoh's heart so that He might show His signs before him. This demonstrates God's sovereign power and glory, consistent with God's purpose in other passages like Romans 9:17-18 and John 9:3 where God's sovereign will is displayed through difficult circumstances.

questions.question: According to Exodus 10, why are the signs and wonders performed in Egypt told to future generations?
options: So they may know the LORD
To keep the memory of Egypt alive
questions.correctAnswer: So they may know the LORD
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:2 explains that the signs are told to sons and grandsons so that they may know the LORD. This highlights God's desire for His people to know and worship Him, paralleling Deuteronomy 6:6-7 and Psalm 78:4 which emphasize passing down God's works for faith and obedience.

questions.question: What warning does Moses give to Pharaoh if he refuses to let the people go?
options: Locusts will cover the land and consume what remains
Darkness will cover the land for three days
The firstborn of Egypt will die
questions.correctAnswer: Locusts will cover the land and consume what remains
questions.explanation: In Exodus 10:4-5, Moses warns Pharaoh that locusts will cover the land and eat every remaining herb and tree after the hail. This plague demonstrates God's judgment on Egypt, consistent with His judgments in Leviticus 26:22 and Revelation 9:3-4 where locusts symbolize divine judgment.

questions.question: How does Pharaoh's attitude toward the Israelites change after the servants advise him?
options: He allows only some of the people to go
He agrees to let all go with their families and livestock
He offers to worship the LORD himself
questions.correctAnswer: He allows only some of the people to go
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:8-11 shows Pharaoh saying, 'Go, serve the LORD your God: but who are they that shall go?' He permits only the men to go, which demonstrates his partial and hardened resistance, aligning with God's purpose to reveal His might (Isaiah 6:9-10; Romans 11:7).

questions.question: What specific action does God command Moses to bring about the plague of locusts?
options: Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt
Throw down the staff before Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:12 directs Moses to stretch out his hand over Egypt to bring the locusts. This act of obedience is a visible sign of God's power, also seen in Exodus 14:21 and Joshua 10:12 where stretching out hands initiates divine intervention.

questions.question: What is the nature of the wind that brings the locusts to Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: A strong east wind
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:13 describes the LORD bringing an east wind that lasted all day and night, which brought the locusts. This wind symbolizes God's sovereign control over nature, similar to the east wind in Jonah 4:8 and the wind that parted the Red Sea in Exodus 14:21.

questions.question: How does the plague of locusts affect the land of Egypt?
options: The land is darkened and all green plants are consumed
Only the crops near the Nile are destroyed
The locusts only damage the houses
The plague causes a famine but leaves plants intact
questions.correctAnswer: The land is darkened and all green plants are consumed
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:15 states that the locusts covered the whole land, darkening it and eating every herb and fruit left after the hail. This total devastation reflects God's judgment as in Joel 1:4-7 and Nahum 3:15 where locusts symbolize utter desolation.

questions.question: What is Pharaoh's response immediately after the locust plague?
options: He admits his sin and asks for forgiveness
He refuses to speak to Moses and Aaron
He calls for more plagues to be stopped
questions.correctAnswer: He admits his sin and asks for forgiveness
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:16-17 records Pharaoh calling Moses and Aaron, confessing his sin against the LORD and asking for forgiveness for the death from the plague. This partial repentance mirrors Jonah 3:9 and David’s confession in Psalm 51:4 but is followed by hardness of heart (Exodus 10:20).

questions.question: How does God remove the locusts from Egypt?
options: A strong west wind blows them into the Red Sea
A heavy rain washes them away
questions.correctAnswer: A strong west wind blows them into the Red Sea
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:19 explains that the LORD sent a mighty west wind to carry the locusts into the Red Sea, removing them completely. This act of deliverance shows God's sovereign control over nature, as also seen in Psalm 104:7-8 and Ezekiel 37:9 where wind symbolizes God's spirit and power.

questions.question: Despite the removal of the locusts, what does God do to Pharaoh's heart?
options: He hardens Pharaoh's heart so he will not let Israel go
He softens Pharaoh's heart to repent
He removes the hardness from Pharaoh's heart
questions.correctAnswer: He hardens Pharaoh's heart so he will not let Israel go
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:20 declares that the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart so he would not let the Israelites go. This reflects God's sovereign judgment and purpose, consistent with Romans 9:17-18 and Isaiah 63:17 where God is sovereign over human will for His glory.

questions.question: What kind of darkness does God command Moses to bring upon Egypt?
options: A thick darkness that may be felt
A cloudy mist in the morning
questions.correctAnswer: A thick darkness that may be felt
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:21-22 describes a thick darkness covering Egypt for three days, so intense it could be felt. This darkness symbolizes God's judgment and is echoed in Joel 2:2 and Amos 5:20 where darkness represents divine wrath.

questions.question: During the three days of darkness, what was the condition of the Israelites?
options: They had light in their dwellings
They were also covered in darkness
They left Egypt during the darkness
They were afflicted by the darkness
questions.correctAnswer: They had light in their dwellings
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:23 states that the Israelites had light in their homes despite the darkness over Egypt, signifying God's protection and distinction of His people, similar to the Passover protection in Exodus 12:23 and the light of God's presence in Isaiah 60:19.

questions.question: What restriction does Pharaoh impose when he finally agrees to let the Israelites go in Exodus 10?
options: Their flocks and herds must remain in Egypt
They must leave without any possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Their flocks and herds must remain in Egypt
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:24 records Pharaoh allowing the Israelites to go but wanting their flocks and herds to stay behind. Moses insists in verses 25-26 that their animals must go to perform sacrifices, showing the importance of worship and obedience to God (cf. Leviticus 1:3, Hebrews 13:15).

questions.question: What is Moses' response to Pharaoh's order to stay away and not see his face again?
options: He agrees and says he will not see Pharaoh's face again
He threatens Pharaoh with more plagues
questions.correctAnswer: He agrees and says he will not see Pharaoh's face again
questions.explanation: Exodus 10:29 shows Moses responding that Pharaoh has spoken well and he will not see his face again. This foreshadows the final confrontation in Exodus 11:1 and Jesus' rejection in John 1:11, highlighting the conflict between God's messenger and hardened opposition.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by God repeatedly hardening Pharaoh's heart in this chapter?
options: God's sovereignty over human will and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereignty over human will and judgment
questions.explanation: The theme of God's sovereignty is emphasized by the repeated hardening of Pharaoh's heart (Exodus 10:1, 20, 27). This reflects God's control over human decisions for His divine purposes, consistent with passages like Romans 9:18 and Isaiah 45:9, underscoring God’s righteous judgment and glory.

questions.question: How does Exodus 10 reflect the doctrine of God’s justice and mercy simultaneously?
options: God judges Egypt but protects Israel
God ignores the cries of the oppressed
God blesses Pharaoh despite his sin
questions.correctAnswer: God judges Egypt but protects Israel
questions.explanation: Exodus 10 shows God executing justice through plagues on Egypt while Israel is spared light and protected (Exodus 10:23). This displays God's justice against sin and mercy toward His covenant people, consistent with Psalm 103:6 and Romans 11:32 where God’s justice and mercy coexist.
